article.headline: KFC, Taco Bell parent Yum Brands' stock gains after sales top expectations
article.body: Shares of Yum Brands Inc. YUM, +0.08% rose 0.2% in premarket trading Thursday, after the parent of the KFC, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell restaurant chains reported second-quarter sales that fell less than forecast, with sales improving as the quarter progressed as restaurants reopened and as digital sales reached record highs. Net income fell to $206 million, or 67 cents a share, from $289 million, or 92 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The results included a 21-cents per share benefit related to the change in fair value of the investment in GrubHub. The FactSet consensus for earnings per share was 54 cents. Total revenue fell 9% to $1.20 billion, but topped the FactSet consensus of $1.18 billion, while the 15% decline in same-store sales missed expectations of a 14.1% drop. KFC same-store sales fell 21%, in line with the FactSet consensus; Pizza Hut same-store sales declined 9%, compared with expectations of an 8.2% decline; and Taco Bell same-store sales fell 8% versus expectations of a 10.7% drop. Habit Burger Grill same-store sales fell 18%. The stock has lost 5.9% year to date through Wednesday, while the S&P 500 SPX, +0.87% has edged up 0.9%.
